G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant acted as Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, including § 14.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Defendant, as Plaintiff’s landlord, is bound by the covenant of quiet enjoyment imposed by G.L. c. 186, § 14, as well as the common law implied covenant recognized in cases such as Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982), and Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses both G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the common-law covenant of quiet enjoyment, treating them as applicable landlord obligations. It explains that every tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, cites Blackett v. Olanoff for that proposition, and then interprets § 14’s “quiet enjoyment” language in light of that common-law covenant. Thus, Simon v. Solomon directly supports the statement that a landlord is bound by both the statutory covenant under § 14 and the common-law implied covenant recognized in Simon and Blackett.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: Defendant, as Plaintiff’s landlord, is bound by the covenant of quiet enjoyment imposed by G.L. c. 186, § 14, as well as the common law implied covenant recognized in cases such as Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982), and Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: Blackett is itself a leading case on the landlord’s implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court expressly recognizes an implied warranty/covenant of quiet enjoyment owed by the landlord and holds that a landlord can breach that covenant (and be subject to constructive eviction) based on conditions the landlord created or could control, regardless of subjective intent. Although G.L. c. 186, § 14 is not mentioned by number in this excerpt, Blackett clearly stands as authority that a landlord is bound by a covenant of quiet enjoyment at common law, consistent with the proposition as to Blackett’s role.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge... There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with the tenancy, including conditions that make the premises unfit for human habitation or substantially interfere with their use. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly defines the covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with the tenancy and applies that standard to conditions (pervasive criminal/drug activity in common areas) that substantially impair the use and enjoyment of the premises. The court states that if tenants cannot use common areas such as sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas, that constitutes a serious interference substantially impairing the character of the leased premises and may breach the covenant, directly aligning with the proposition’s description of substantial interference with use.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold. … In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with the tenancy, including conditions that make the premises unfit for human habitation or substantially interfere with their use. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994); Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on the fault requirement for liability under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, but in doing so it reaffirms the nature of § 14 as protecting tenants from serious interferences with their tenancy, especially where landlords fail to remedy known defects that affect habitability or use. The court cites earlier quiet-enjoyment cases involving uninhabitable or substantially impaired premises (e.g., failure to repair a leaky roof, failure to keep an apartment habitable) as paradigmatic § 14 violations, thereby supporting the proposition that the covenant covers serious interference, including conditions rendering premises unfit or substantially interfering with their use.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain the premises so as to comply with the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979); Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771 (1994).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely ties the landlord’s contractual/warranty obligations to compliance with the State Sanitary Code and treats substantial Sanitary Code violations (including failure to provide adequate heat and hot water) as breaches of the landlord’s obligations affecting the tenant’s rent obligations. While the case is framed in terms of the implied warranty of habitability rather than the covenant of quiet enjoyment, it expressly states that a dwelling with substantial Sanitary Code violations is not habitable and that the landlord must at least comply with State sanitary and building codes—principles that Massachusetts cases later apply under quiet enjoyment as well. Thus, it supports the broader proposition that failure to comply with the State Sanitary Code can constitute a breach of the landlord’s protective covenants toward the tenant.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation.’ Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, supra at 196-197. A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. … In the latter instance, the landlord must comply at least with minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes. Whether the scope of the warranty is broader is an open question. Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443, 451 (1979).”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.proposition: A landlord’s failure to maintain the premises so as to comply with the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979); Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771 (1994).
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses breach of the implied warranty of habitability, damages, and related statutory claims, and notes only in passing that the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. It does not analyze what constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it link such a breach to violations of the State Sanitary Code. The case is therefore not authority for the specific proposition that failure to comply with the State Sanitary Code can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Wideman, 417 Mass. 771.relevant_excerpt: Although the judge found a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, he awarded no damages on this claim to avoid what would have been a duplicative award. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 107-111 (1982).

Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..raw_text: Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass. 708 (2002)
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that a landlord’s failure to correct serious defective conditions after notice can amount to a constructive eviction or breach of quiet enjoyment. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982); Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994);  Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass. 708 (2002).
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..support_reasoning: The case discusses constructive eviction and breach of quiet enjoyment generally, but it ultimately holds that the landlord’s failure to repair the leaking roof did NOT amount to a constructive eviction because the premises were not shown to be untenantable. Instead, the tenant prevailed under the newly adopted rule of mutually dependent covenants, not on constructive eviction or quiet enjoyment grounds. Thus, Wesson does not stand for the proposition that a landlord’s failure to correct serious defective conditions after notice can be a constructive eviction or breach of quiet enjoyment; it rejects that characterization on these facts.
Wesson v. Leone Enters., Inc., 437 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “While the landlord’s breach of his covenant to repair may have made the tenant’s operation less convenient and more expensive, based on the evidence adduced at trial, it did not rise to the level of a constructive eviction… The judge’s finding of constructive eviction was in error, but because we adopt the rule of mutually dependent covenants for commercial leases and conclude that the plaintiff landlord breached his covenant to maintain the roof, the tenant was entitled to terminate the lease and recover relocation costs.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violates the public policy of the Commonwealth that residential premises comply with the implied warranty of habitability. See Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973); Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196 (1979).
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is from a concurrence/dissent, not the majority, but Hemingway as a whole is the seminal Massachusetts case recognizing an implied warranty of habitability for residential premises as a matter of public policy. Justice Quirico’s opinion explicitly ties the landlord’s obligation to comply with the State Sanitary Code and labels agreements waiving these statutory protections as against public policy. Thus, while this excerpt is not the core majority holding, the case generally supports the proposition that noncompliance with the implied warranty of habitability contravenes Commonwealth public policy.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: "By G. L. c. 111, § 127C, as amended by St. 1969, c. 242, and § 127H, as amended by St. 1972, c. 201, a tenant may file a petition in the District or Superior Court to enforce compliance with the Code by the landlord; and by § 127K, inserted by St. 1968, c. 404, § 2, any agreement by the tenant to waive that right is declared to be against public policy and void."
